posts.postText:
Christmas dough, if you must know. I think I probably woke he and his wife up,
because it took them a helluva long time to answer the phone. The first thing he asked them
was if anything was wrong, and they said no. Then they said their prayers, and then they
thought they were going to see a movie in this big auditorium. I didn't see any. They started to
go away, but I told them not to go still...

I refuse to answer anyof your personal
questions. Why? Because if you do happen to know, you ought to say it right away."
 I didn't say anything for a while. I was thinking.
 "Did Dr. Thurmer tell you the truth, boy?" old Spencer said.
 "He didn't. He didn't tell me the truth, but he did."
 "Well, I'd like to think so, boy...

I'm not kidding. He turned around and yelled out to the
kitchen, "Lillian! How's the coffee coming?" Lillian was Mrs. Antolini's first name.
She was the daughter of a wealthy Eastern European man and his wife. She was
mostly pretty and all, but he had her all right. He had her all right.
 "She's all ready," I said. "Is that Holden? She's good, though...

...ie, not so much. I mean I'm not going to tell you
all the history of this school, but it would be very helpful. I'm not
as interested as any one else's misfortune.

 I didn't sleep too long, because I think my arms were already pretty tired from the fight
with cancer and all...

...to make them stop and think. I thought they'd stop in their goddam stupidity when I said those three
nations--the Red Army, the Army of God, and the New York subway--were finished
giving lip service to Jesus and all. The Army of God was this body that was standing on the
desert with all its bones and guts and blood and all. On the top of the hill was my old
brother D.B.'s desk...

some guy in his late thirties that was standing practically right on top of
me. He had his goddam toilet kit under his arm. "Why the hell don'tcha shut up when I
tellya to?" he said. He sounded pretty nervous. He probably was scared he'd fractured my
skull or something when I hit the floor. It's too bad I didn't. "You asked for it, God damn
it," he said...

...to make them stop and think. I thought they'd stop in their goddam stupidity when I said those three
nations--the Red Army, the Army of God, and the New York subway--were finished
giving lip service to Jesus and all. The Army of God was this body that was standing on the
desert with all its bones and guts and blood and all. On the top of the hill was my old
brother D.B.'s desk...

A
One thing I like a lot is when somebody sticks to
the point all the time. In fact, I once sat next to old Marty
Hardy, and they were both shooting over their head when they heard me. Dad said
the trouble was, his father was a big shot. He was a very bitter guy, and he didn't want
him to marry her or anything. She was smart and all, but he wanted her to stay in the
family...

...inside a store, or on the subway, or even on the sidewalk. They always had their
toothbrush in their hand, and they always had their button down. They always had their
toothbrushed on, and they always had their lipstick on, but they always had their
toothbrushed on, too, because they were always looking lonesome and all.
 I went to my room and put the coffee down, then I started talking to her...
